p: A total of 53 plant species belonging to 30 families were reported for their anticancer use ( Table 3). The result of this study showed that shrubs (49.1%), herbs (33.9%), trees (13.2%), and climbers (3.8%) were the main sources of potential anticancer medicinal plants. This study also indicated that leaves (56.7%) were the most commonly used plant parts followed by roots (21.7%), bark (6.7%), stem (1.7%), seeds (1.7%), whole plant (1.7%), leaves and roots (5%), leaves or stem (1.7%), and leaves or seeds (1.7%) ( Figure 3). Most of the reported plants occurred naturally in wild (96.2%); however, cultivation was also a source (3.8%). Reported medicinal plants have been traditionally claimed to be used to treat different types of ailments including cancer. However, only few have been scientifically investigated for their antiproliferative or cytotoxic activity ( Table 4). While comparing the amount and distribution of anticancer plants in the past ten years, regardless of the study areas, all respondents believed that the amount and distribution of these plants are reduced.
